InstanceList.description: A comma-delimited list of server ip addresses. (Heat extension).

Tags.description: Tags to attach to this group.

InstanceId.description: The ID of an existing instance to use to create the Auto Scaling group. If specify this property, will create the group use an existing instance instead of a launch configuration.

MinSize.description: Minimum number of instances in the group.

MaxSize.description: Maximum number of instances in the group.

VPCZoneIdentifier.description: Use only with Neutron, to list the internal subnet to which the instance will be attached; needed only if multiple exist; list length must be exactly 1.

*.description: UUID of the internal subnet to which the instance will be attached.

LaunchConfigurationName.description: The reference to a LaunchConfiguration resource.

UserData.description: User data to pass to instance.

InstanceId.description: The ID of an existing instance you want to use to create the launch configuration. All properties are derived from the instance with the exception of BlockDeviceMapping.

BlockDeviceMappings.description: Block device mappings to attach to instance.

Ebs.description: The ebs volume to attach to the instance.

SnapshotId.description: The ID of the snapshot to create a volume from.

DeleteOnTermination.description: Indicate whether the volume should be deleted when the instance is terminated.

VolumeSize.description: The size of the volume, in GB. Must be equal or greater than the size of the snapshot. It is safe to leave this blank and have the Compute service infer the size.

Iops.description: The number of I/O operations per second that the volume supports.

DeviceName.description: A device name where the volume will be attached in the system at /dev/device_name.e.g. vdb

VirtualName.description: The name of the virtual device. The name must be in the form ephemeralX where X is a number starting from zero (0); for example, ephemeral0.

NoDevice.description: The can be used to unmap a defined device.

NovaSchedulerHints.description: Scheduler hints to pass to Nova (Heat extension).

AlarmUrl.description: A signed url to handle the alarm. (Heat extension).

AutoScalingGroupName.description: AutoScaling group name to apply policy to.

MinAdjustmentStep.description: Minimum number of resources that are added or removed when the AutoScaling group scales up or down. This can be used only when specifying PercentChangeInCapacity for the AdjustmentType property.

AWS::CloudFormation::Stack.description: Represents a child stack to allow composition of templates.

TemplateURL.description: The URL of a template that specifies the stack to be created as a resource.

TimeoutInMinutes.description: The length of time, in minutes, to wait for the nested stack creation.

Parameters.description: The set of parameters passed to this nested stack.

Data.description: JSON string containing data associated with wait condition signals sent to the handle.

Count.description: The number of success signals that must be received before the stack creation process continues.

Handle.description: A reference to the wait condition handle used to signal this wait condition.

Timeout.description: The number of seconds to wait for the correct number of signals to arrive.

AWS::CloudFormation::WaitConditionHandle.description:
AWS WaitConditionHandle resource.

the main point of this class is to :
have no dependencies (so the instance can reference it)
generate a unique url (to be returned in the reference)
then the cfn-signal will use this url to post to and
WaitCondition will poll it to see if has been written to.

AllocationId.description: ID that AWS assigns to represent the allocation of the address for use with Amazon VPC. Returned only for VPC elastic IP addresses.

InstanceId.description: Instance ID to associate with EIP.

Domain.description: Set to "vpc" to have IP address allocation associated to your VPC.

InstanceId.description: Instance ID to associate with EIP specified by EIP property.

EIP.description: EIP address to associate with instance.

NetworkInterfaceId.description: Network interface ID to associate with EIP.

AllocationId.description: Allocation ID for VPC EIP address.

AvailabilityZone.description: The Availability Zone where the specified instance is launched.

PublicDnsName.description: Public DNS name of the specified instance.

PrivateIp.description: Private IP address of the specified instance.

PublicIp.description: Public IP address of the specified instance.

PrivateDnsName.description: Private DNS name of the specified instance.

UserData.description: User data to pass to instance.

AvailabilityZone.description: Availability zone to launch the instance in.

BlockDeviceMappings.description: Block device mappings to attach to instance.

Ebs.description: The ebs volume to attach to the instance.

SnapshotId.description: The ID of the snapshot to create a volume from.

DeleteOnTermination.description: Indicate whether the volume should be deleted when the instance is terminated.

VolumeSize.description: The size of the volume, in GB. Must be equal or greater than the size of the snapshot. It is safe to leave this blank and have the Compute service infer the size.

Iops.description: The number of I/O operations per second that the volume supports.

DeviceName.description: A device name where the volume will be attached in the system at /dev/device_name.e.g. vdb

VirtualName.description: The name of the virtual device. The name must be in the form ephemeralX where X is a number starting from zero (0); for example, ephemeral0.

NoDevice.description: The can be used to unmap a defined device.

Device.description: The device where the volume is exposed on the instance. This assignment may not be honored and it is advised that the path /dev/disk/by-id/virtio-<VolumeId> be used instead.

VolumeId.description: The ID of the volume to be attached.

SubnetId.description: Subnet ID to launch instance in.

NovaSchedulerHints.description: Scheduler hints to pass to Nova (Heat extension).

NetworkInterfaces.description: Network interfaces to associate with instance.

PrivateIpAddress.description: Private IP address of the network interface.

SubnetId.description: Subnet ID to associate with this interface.

GroupSet.description: List of security group IDs associated with this interface.

*.description: List of tags associated with this interface.

VpcId.description: VPC ID for where the route table is created.

*.description: List of tags to be attached to this resource.
List of security group ingress rules.

VpcId.description: Physical ID of the VPC. Not implemented.

*.description: List of security group egress rules.
List of tags to attach to this resource.

VpcId.description: Ref structure that contains the ID of the VPC on which you want to create the subnet.

CidrBlock.description: CIDR block to apply to subnet.

AvailabilityZone.description: Availability zone in which you want the subnet.

Size.description: The size of the volume in GB.

SnapshotId.description: If specified, the backup used as the source to create the volume.

AvailabilityZone.description: The availability zone in which the volume will be created.

Tags.description: The list of tags to associate with the volume.

InstanceId.description: The ID of the instance to which the volume attaches.

Device.description: The device where the volume is exposed on the instance. This assignment may not be honored and it is advised that the path /dev/disk/by-id/virtio-<VolumeId> be used instead.

VolumeId.description: The ID of the volume to be attached.

CidrBlock.description: CIDR block to apply to the VPC.

*.description: List of tags to attach to the instance.

VpcId.description: VPC ID for this gateway association.

AWS::ElasticLoadBalancing::LoadBalancer.description:
Implements a HAProxy-bearing instance as a nested stack.

The template for the nested stack can be redefined with
``loadbalancer_template`` option in ``heat.conf``.

Generally the image used for the instance must have the following
packages installed or available for installation at runtime::

- heat-cfntools and its dependencies like python-psutil
- cronie
- socat
- haproxy

Current default builtin template uses Fedora 21 x86_64 base cloud image
(https://getfedora.org/cloud/download/)
and apart from installing packages goes through some hoops
around SELinux due to pecularities of heat-cfntools.

SourceSecurityGroup.GroupName.description: The security group that you can use as part of your inbound rules for your LoadBalancer's back-end instances.

CanonicalHostedZoneNameID.description: The ID of the hosted zone name that is associated with the LoadBalancer.

CanonicalHostedZoneName.description: The name of the hosted zone that is associated with the LoadBalancer.

SourceSecurityGroup.OwnerAlias.description: Owner of the source security group.

DNSName.description: The DNS name for the LoadBalancer.

Instances.description: The list of instance IDs load balanced.

Listeners.description: One or more listeners for this load balancer.

InstancePort.description: TCP port on which the instance server is listening.

Protocol.description: The load balancer transport protocol to use.

LoadBalancerPort.description: The external load balancer port number.

AvailabilityZones.description: The Availability Zones in which to create the load balancer.

SecurityGroups.description: List of Security Groups assigned on current LB.

HealthCheck.description: An application health check for the instances.

HealthyThreshold.description: The number of consecutive health probe successes required before moving the instance to the healthy state.

Interval.description: The approximate interval, in seconds, between health checks of an individual instance.

UnhealthyThreshold.description: The number of consecutive health probe failures required before moving the instance to the unhealthy state

UserName.description: The name of the user that the new key will belong to.

LoginProfile.description: A login profile for the user.

Policies.description: Access policies to apply to the user.

OS::Aodh::CombinationAlarm.description:
A resource that implements combination of Aodh alarms.

Allows to use alarm as a combination of other alarms with some operator:
activate this alarm if any alarm in combination has been activated or
if all alarms in combination have been activated.

support_status.message: The combination alarm is deprecated and disabled by default in Aodh.

alarm_actions.description: A list of URLs (webhooks) to invoke when state transitions to alarm.

ok_actions.description: A list of URLs (webhooks) to invoke when state transitions to ok.

enabled.description: True if alarm evaluation/actioning is enabled.

alarm_ids.description: List of alarm identifiers to combine.

time_constraints.description: Describe time constraints for the alarm. Only evaluate the alarm if the time at evaluation is within this time constraint. Start point(s) of the constraint are specified with a cron expression, whereas its duration is given in seconds.

start.description: Start time for the time constraint. A CRON expression property.

insufficient_data_queues.description: A list of Zaqar queues to post to when state transitions to insufficient-data.

ok_queues.description: A list of Zaqar queues to post to when state transitions to ok.

insufficient_data_actions.description: A list of URLs (webhooks) to invoke when state transitions to insufficient-data.

repeat_actions.description: False to trigger actions when the threshold is reached AND the alarm's state has changed. By default, actions are called each time the threshold is reached.

operator.description: Operator used to combine the alarms.

alarm_queues.description: A list of Zaqar queues to post to when state transitions to alarm.

OS::Cinder::Volume.description:
A resource that implements Cinder volumes.

Cinder volume is a storage in the form of block devices. It can be used,
for example, for providing storage to instance. Volume supports creation
from snapshot, backup or image. Also volume can be created only by size.

status.description: The current status of the volume.

metadata_values.description: Key/value pairs associated with the volume in raw dict form.

attachments.description: The list of attachments of the volume.

availability_zone.description: The availability zone in which the volume is located.

bootable.description: Boolean indicating if the volume can be booted or not.

encrypted.description: Boolean indicating if the volume is encrypted or not.

multiattach.description: Boolean indicating whether allow the volume to be attached more than once.

source_volid.description: The volume used as source, if any.

snapshot_id.description: The snapshot the volume was created from, if any.

metadata.description: Key/value pairs associated with the volume.

volume_type.description: The type of the volume mapping to a backend, if any.

size.description: The size of the volume in GB.

read_only.description: Enables or disables read-only access mode of volume.

backup_id.description: If specified, the backup to create the volume from.

multiattach.description: Whether allow the volume to be attached more than once.

image.description: If specified, the name or ID of the image to create the volume from.

availability_zone.description: The availability zone in which the volume will be created.

metadata.description: Key/value pairs to associate with the volume.

source_volid.description: If specified, the volume to use as source.

name.description: A name used to distinguish the volume.

volume_type.description: If specified, the type of volume to use, mapping to a specific backend.

snapshot_id.description: If specified, the snapshot to create the volume from.

scheduler_hints.description: Arbitrary key-value pairs specified by the client to help the Cinder scheduler creating a volume.

size.description: The size of the volume in GB. On update only increase in size is supported. This property is required unless property backup_id or source_volid or snapshot_id is specified.

OS::Cinder::VolumeAttachment.description:
Resource for associating volume to instance.

Resource for associating existing volume to instance. Also, the location
where the volume is exposed on the instance can be specified.

instance_uuid.description: The ID of the server to which the volume attaches.

mountpoint.description: The location where the volume is exposed on the instance. This assignment may not be honored and it is advised that the path /dev/disk/by-id/virtio-<VolumeId> be used instead.

volume_id.description: The ID of the volume to be attached.

OS::Glance::Image.description:
A resource managing images in Glance.

A resource provides managing images that are meant to be used with other
services.

support_status.message: Creating a Glance Image based on an existing URL location requires the Glance v1 API, which is deprecated.

os_distro.description: The common name of the operating system distribution in lowercase.

name.description: Name for the image. The name of an image is not unique to a Image Service node.

extra_properties.description: Arbitrary properties to associate with the image.

kernel_id.description: ID of image stored in Glance that should be used as the kernel when booting an AMI-style image.

min_ram.description: Amount of ram (in MB) required to boot image. Default value is 0 if not specified and means no limit on the ram size.

ramdisk_id.description: ID of image stored in Glance that should be used as the ramdisk when booting an AMI-style image.

min_disk.description: Amount of disk space (in GB) required to boot image. Default value is 0 if not specified and means no limit on the disk size.

protected.description: Whether the image can be deleted. If the value is True, the image is protected and cannot be deleted.

location.description: URL where the data for this image already resides. For example, if the image data is stored in swift, you could specify "swift://example.com/container/obj".

is_public.description: Scope of image accessibility. Public or private. Default value is False means private. Note: The policy setting of glance allows only users with admin roles to create public image by default.

id.description: The image ID. Glance will generate a UUID if not specified.

OS::Heat::AccessPolicy.description:
Resource for defining which resources can be accessed by users.

NOTE: Now this resource is actually associated with an AWS user resource,
not any OS:: resource though it is registered under the OS namespace below.

Resource for defining resources that users are allowed to access by the
DescribeStackResource API.

AllowedResources.description: Resources that users are allowed to access by the DescribeStackResource API.

OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup.description:
An autoscaling group that can scale arbitrary resources.

An autoscaling group allows the creation of a desired count of similar
resources, which are defined with the resource property in HOT format.
If there is a need to create many of the same resources (e.g. one
hundred sets of Server, WaitCondition and WaitConditionHandle or even
Neutron Nets), AutoScalingGroup is a convenient and easy way to do that.

outputs.description: A map of resource names to the specified attribute of each individual resource that is part of the AutoScalingGroup. This map specifies output parameters that are available once the AutoScalingGroup has been instantiated.

refs.description: A list of resource IDs for the resources in the group.

outputs_list.description: A list of the specified attribute of each individual resource that is part of the AutoScalingGroup. This list of attributes is available as an output once the AutoScalingGroup has been instantiated.

refs_map.description: A map of resource names to IDs for the resources in the group.

resource.description: Resource definition for the resources in the group, in HOT format. The value of this property is the definition of a resource just as if it had been declared in the template itself.

min_size.description: Minimum number of resources in the group.

rolling_updates.description: Policy for rolling updates for this scaling group.

min_in_service.description: The minimum number of resources in service while rolling updates are being executed.

pause_time.description: The number of seconds to wait between batches of updates.

max_batch_size.description: The maximum number of resources to replace at once.

max_size.description: Maximum number of resources in the group.

OS::Heat::CloudConfig.description:
A configuration resource for representing cloud-init cloud-config.

This resource allows cloud-config YAML to be defined and stored by the
config API. Any intrinsic functions called in the config will be resolved
before storing the result.

This resource will generally be referenced by OS::Nova::Server user_data,
or OS::Heat::MultipartMime parts config. Since cloud-config is boot-only
configuration, any changes to the definition will result in the
replacement of all servers which reference it.

config.description: The config value of the software config.

cloud_config.description: Map representing the cloud-config data structure which will be formatted as YAML.

OS::Heat::DeployedServer.description:
A resource for managing servers that are already deployed.

A DeployedServer resource manages resources for servers that have been
deployed externally from OpenStack. These servers can be associated with
SoftwareDeployments for further orchestration via Heat.

metadata.description: Arbitrary key/value metadata to store for this server. Both keys and values must be 255 characters or less. Non-string values will be serialized to JSON (and the serialized string must be 255 characters or less).

software_config_transport.description: How the server should receive the metadata required for software configuration. POLL_SERVER_CFN will allow calls to the cfn API action DescribeStackResource authenticated with the provided keypair. POLL_SERVER_HEAT will allow calls to the Heat API resource-show using the provided keystone credentials. POLL_TEMP_URL will create and populate a Swift TempURL with metadata for polling. ZAQAR_MESSAGE will create a dedicated zaqar queue and post the metadata for polling.

support_status.message: The HARestarter resource type is deprecated and will be removed in a future release of Heat, once it has support for auto-healing any type of resource. Note that HARestarter does *not* actually restart servers - it deletes and then recreates them. It also does the same to all dependent resources, and may therefore exhibit unexpected and undesirable behaviour. Instead, use the mark-unhealthy API to mark a resource as needing replacement, and then a stack update to perform the replacement while respecting  the dependencies and not deleting them unnecessarily.

AlarmUrl.description: A signed url to handle the alarm (Heat extension).

OS::Heat::InstanceGroup.description:
An instance group that can scale arbitrary instances.

A resource allowing for the creating number of defined with
AWS::AutoScaling::LaunchConfiguration instances. Allows to associate
scaled resources with loadbalancer resources.

InstanceList.description: A comma-delimited list of server ip addresses. (Heat extension).

Tags.description: Tags to attach to this group.

LaunchConfigurationName.description: The reference to a LaunchConfiguration resource.

OS::Heat::MultipartMime.description:
Assembles a collection of software configurations as a multi-part mime.

Parts in the message can be populated with inline configuration or
references to other config resources. If the referenced resource is itself
a valid multi-part mime message, that will be broken into parts and
those parts appended to this message.

The resulting multi-part mime message will be stored by the configs API
and can be referenced in properties such as OS::Nova::Server user_data.

This resource is generally used to build a list of cloud-init
configuration elements including scripts and cloud-config. Since
cloud-init is boot-only configuration, any changes to the definition
will result in the replacement of all servers which reference it.

config.description: The config value of the software config.

subtype.description: Optional subtype to specify with the type.

type.description: Whether the part content is text or multipart.

config.description: Content of part to attach, either inline or by referencing the ID of another software config resource.

filename.description: Optional filename to associate with part.

OS::Heat::None.description:
Enables easily disabling certain resources via the resource_registry.

It does nothing, but can effectively stub out any other resource because it
will accept any properties and return any attribute (as None). Note this
resource always does nothing on update (e.g it is not replaced even if a
change to the stubbed resource properties would cause replacement).

OS::Heat::RandomString.description:
A resource which generates a random string.

This is useful for configuring passwords and secrets on services. Random
string can be generated from specified character sequences, which means
that all characters will be randomly chosen from specified sequences, or
with some classes, e.g. letterdigits, which means that all character will
be randomly chosen from union of ascii letters and digits. Output string
will be randomly generated string with specified length (or with length of
32, if length property doesn't specified).

value.description: The random string generated by this resource. This value is also available by referencing the resource.

length.description: Length of the string to generate.

salt.description: Value which can be set or changed on stack update to trigger the resource for replacement with a new random string. The salt value itself is ignored by the random generator.

character_sequences.description: A list of character sequences and their constraints to generate the random string from.

sequence.description: A character sequence and its corresponding min constraint to generate the random string from.

min.description: The minimum number of characters from this sequence that will be in the generated string.

character_classes.description: A list of character class and their constraints to generate the random string from.

class.description: A character class and its corresponding min constraint to generate the random string from.

min.description: The minimum number of characters from this character class that will be in the generated string.

OS::Heat::ResourceChain.description:
Creates one or more resources with the same configuration.

The types of resources to be created are passed into the chain
through the ``resources`` property. One resource will be created for each
type listed. Each is passed the configuration specified
under ``resource_properties``.

The ``concurrent`` property controls if the resources will be created
concurrently. If omitted or set to false, each resource will be treated
as having a dependency on the resource before it in the list.

attributes.description: A map of resource names to the specified attribute of each individual resource.

refs.description: A list of resource IDs for the resources in the chain.

concurrent.description: If true, the resources in the chain will be created concurrently. If false or omitted, each resource will be treated as having a dependency on the previous resource in the list.

resource_properties.description: Properties to pass to each resource being created in the chain.

resources.description: The list of resource types to create. This list may contain type names or aliases defined in the resource registry. Specific template names are not supported.

OS::Heat::ResourceGroup.description:
Creates one or more identically configured nested resources.

In addition to the `refs` attribute, this resource implements synthetic
attributes that mirror those of the resources in the group. When
getting an attribute from this resource, however, a list of attribute
values for each resource in the group is returned. To get attribute values
for a single resource in the group, synthetic attributes of the form
`resource.{resource index}.{attribute name}` can be used. The resource ID
of a particular resource in the group can be obtained via the synthetic
attribute `resource.{resource index}`. Note, that if you get attribute
without `{resource index}`, e.g. `[resource, {attribute_name}]`, you'll get
a list of this attribute's value for all resources in group.

While each resource in the group will be identically configured, this
resource does allow for some index-based customization of the properties
of the resources in the group. For example::

resources:
my_indexed_group:
type: OS::Heat::ResourceGroup
properties:
count: 3
resource_def:
type: OS::Nova::Server
properties:
# create a unique name for each server
# using its index in the group
name: my_server_%index%
image: CentOS 6.5
flavor: 4GB Performance

would result in a group of three servers having the same image and flavor,
but names of `my_server_0`, `my_server_1`, and `my_server_2`. The variable
used for substitution can be customized by using the `index_var` property.

attributes.description: A map of resource names to the specified attribute of each individual resource. Requires heat_template_version: 2014-10-16.

refs.description: A list of resource IDs for the resources in the group.

refs_map.description: A map of resource names to IDs for the resources in the group.

removed_rsrc_list.description: A list of removed resource names.

count.description: The number of resources to create.

resource_def.description: Resource definition for the resources in the group. The value of this property is the definition of a resource just as if it had been declared in the template itself.

type.description: The type of the resources in the group.

properties.description: Property values for the resources in the group.

metadata.description: Supplied metadata for the resources in the group.

removal_policies.description: Policies for removal of resources on update.

*.description: Policy to be processed when doing an update which requires removal of specific resources.

resource_list.description: List of resources to be removed when doing an update which requires removal of specific resources. The resource may be specified several ways: (1) The resource name, as in the nested stack, (2) The resource reference returned from get_resource in a template, as available via the 'refs' attribute. Note this is destructive on update when specified; even if the count is not being reduced, and once a resource name is removed, it's name is never reused in subsequent updates.

index_var.description: A variable that this resource will use to replace with the current index of a given resource in the group. Can be used, for example, to customize the name property of grouped servers in order to differentiate them when listed with nova client.

OS::Heat::ScalingPolicy.description:
A resource to manage scaling of `OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup`.

**Note** while it may incidentally support
`AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup` for now, please don't use it for that
purpose and use `AWS::AutoScaling::ScalingPolicy` instead.

Resource to manage scaling for `OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup`, i.e. define
which metric should be scaled and scaling adjustment, set cooldown etc.

alarm_url.description: A signed url to handle the alarm.

signal_url.description: A url to handle the alarm using native API.

auto_scaling_group_id.description: AutoScaling group ID to apply policy to.

min_adjustment_step.description: Minimum number of resources that are added or removed when the AutoScaling group scales up or down. This can be used only when specifying percent_change_in_capacity for the adjustment_type property.

OS::Heat::SoftwareComponent.description:
A resource for describing and storing a software component.

This resource is similar to OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig. In contrast to
SoftwareConfig which allows for storing only one configuration (e.g. one
script), SoftwareComponent allows for storing multiple configurations to
address handling of all lifecycle hooks (CREATE, UPDATE, SUSPEND, RESUME,
DELETE) for a software component in one place.

This resource is backed by the persistence layer and the API of the
SoftwareConfig resource, and only adds handling for the additional
'configs' property and attribute.

config.description: The config value of the software config.

inputs.description: Schema representing the inputs that this software config is expecting.

default.description: Default value for the input if none is specified.

type.description: Type of the value of the input.

replace_on_change.description: Replace the deployment instead of updating it when the input value changes.

configs.description: The list of configurations for the different lifecycle actions of the represented software component.

tool.description: The configuration tool used to actually apply the configuration on a server. This string property has to be understood by in-instance tools running inside deployed servers.

config.description: Configuration script or manifest which specifies what actual configuration is performed.

actions.description: Lifecycle actions to which the configuration applies. The string values provided for this property can include the standard resource actions CREATE, DELETE, UPDATE, SUSPEND and RESUME supported by Heat.

options.description: Map containing options specific to the configuration management tool used by this resource.

outputs.description: Schema representing the outputs that this software config will produce.

type.description: Type of the value of the output.

error_output.description: Denotes that the deployment is in an error state if this output has a value.

OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig.description:
A resource for describing and storing software configuration.

The software_configs API which backs this resource creates immutable
configs, so any change to the template resource definition will result
in a new config being created, and the old one being deleted.

Configs can be defined in the same template which uses them, or they can
be created in one stack, and passed to another stack via a parameter.

A config resource can be referenced in other resource properties which
are config-aware. This includes the properties OS::Nova::Server user_data,
OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment config and OS::Heat::MultipartMime parts
config.

Along with the config script itself, this resource can define schemas for
inputs and outputs which the config script is expected to consume and
produce. Inputs and outputs are optional and will map to concepts which
are specific to the configuration tool being used.

config.description: The config value of the software config.

inputs.description: Schema representing the inputs that this software config is expecting.

default.description: Default value for the input if none is specified.

type.description: Type of the value of the input.

replace_on_change.description: Replace the deployment instead of updating it when the input value changes.

config.description: Configuration script or manifest which specifies what actual configuration is performed.

options.description: Map containing options specific to the configuration management tool used by this resource.

outputs.description: Schema representing the outputs that this software config will produce.

type.description: Type of the value of the output.

error_output.description: Denotes that the deployment is in an error state if this output has a value.

group.description: Namespace to group this software config by when delivered to a server. This may imply what configuration tool is going to perform the configuration.

OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment.description:
This resource associates a server with some configuration.

The configuration is to be deployed to that server.

A deployment allows input values to be specified which map to the inputs
schema defined in the config resource. These input values are interpreted
by the configuration tool in a tool-specific manner.

Whenever this resource goes to an IN_PROGRESS state, it creates an
ephemeral config that includes the inputs values plus a number of extra
inputs which have names prefixed with deploy_. The extra inputs relate
to the current state of the stack, along with the information and
credentials required to signal back the deployment results.

Unless signal_transport=NO_SIGNAL, this resource will remain in an
IN_PROGRESS state until the server signals it with the output values
for that deployment. Those output values are then available as resource
attributes, along with the default attributes deploy_stdout,
deploy_stderr and deploy_status_code.

Specifying actions other than the default CREATE and UPDATE will result
in the deployment being triggered in those actions. For example this would
allow cleanup configuration to be performed during actions SUSPEND and
DELETE. A config could be designed to only work with some specific
actions, or a config can read the value of the deploy_action input to
allow conditional logic to perform different configuration for different
actions.

deploy_stdout.description: Captured stdout from the configuration execution.

deploy_stderr.description: Captured stderr from the configuration execution.

deploy_status_code.description: Returned status code from the configuration execution.

signal_transport.description: How the server should signal to heat with the deployment output values. CFN_SIGNAL will allow an HTTP POST to a CFN keypair signed URL. TEMP_URL_SIGNAL will create a Swift TempURL to be signaled via HTTP PUT. HEAT_SIGNAL will allow calls to the Heat API resource-signal using the provided keystone credentials. ZAQAR_SIGNAL will create a dedicated zaqar queue to be signaled using the provided keystone credentials. NO_SIGNAL will result in the resource going to the COMPLETE state without waiting for any signal.

name.description: Name of the derived config associated with this deployment. This is used to apply a sort order to the list of configurations currently deployed to a server.

actions.description: Which lifecycle actions of the deployment resource will result in this deployment being triggered.

server.description: ID of resource to apply configuration to. Normally this should be a Nova server ID.

input_values.description: Input values to apply to the software configuration on this server.

config.description: ID of software configuration resource to execute when applying to the server.

OS::Heat::SoftwareDeploymentGroup.description:
This resource associates a group of servers with some configuration.

The configuration is to be deployed to all servers in the group.

The properties work in a similar way to OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment,
and in addition to the attributes documented, you may pass any
attribute supported by OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment, including those
exposing arbitrary outputs, and return a map of deployment names to
the specified attribute.

deploy_stderrs.description: A map of Nova names and captured stderrs from the configuration execution to each server.

deploy_stdouts.description: A map of Nova names and captured stdouts from the configuration execution to each server.

deploy_status_codes.description: A map of Nova names and returned status code from the configuration execution.

signal_transport.description: How the server should signal to heat with the deployment output values. CFN_SIGNAL will allow an HTTP POST to a CFN keypair signed URL. TEMP_URL_SIGNAL will create a Swift TempURL to be signaled via HTTP PUT. HEAT_SIGNAL will allow calls to the Heat API resource-signal using the provided keystone credentials. ZAQAR_SIGNAL will create a dedicated zaqar queue to be signaled using the provided keystone credentials. NO_SIGNAL will result in the resource going to the COMPLETE state without waiting for any signal.

name.description: Name of the derived config associated with this deployment. This is used to apply a sort order to the list of configurations currently deployed to a server.

actions.description: Which lifecycle actions of the deployment resource will result in this deployment being triggered.

servers.description: A map of names and server IDs to apply configuration to. The name is arbitrary and is used as the Heat resource name for the corresponding deployment.

input_values.description: Input values to apply to the software configuration on this server.

config.description: ID of software configuration resource to execute when applying to the server.

OS::Heat::Stack.description:
A Resource representing a stack.

A resource that allowing for the creating stack, where should be defined
stack template in HOT format, parameters (if template has any parameters
with no default value), and timeout of creating. After creating current
stack will have remote stack.

outputs.description: A dict of key-value pairs output from the stack.

region_name.description: Region name in which this stack will be created.

parameters.description: Set of parameters passed to this stack.

timeout.description: Number of minutes to wait for this stack creation.

template.description: Template that specifies the stack to be created as a resource.

OS::Heat::StructuredConfig.description:
A resource which has same logic with OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig.

This resource is like OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig except that the config
property is represented by a Map rather than a String.

This is useful for configuration tools which use YAML or JSON as their
configuration syntax. The resulting configuration is transferred,
stored and returned by the software_configs API as parsed JSON.

config.description: The config value of the software config.

inputs.description: Schema representing the inputs that this software config is expecting.

default.description: Default value for the input if none is specified.

type.description: Type of the value of the input.

replace_on_change.description: Replace the deployment instead of updating it when the input value changes.

config.description: Map representing the configuration data structure which will be serialized to JSON format.

options.description: Map containing options specific to the configuration management tool used by this resource.

outputs.description: Schema representing the outputs that this software config will produce.

type.description: Type of the value of the output.

error_output.description: Denotes that the deployment is in an error state if this output has a value.

group.description: Namespace to group this software config by when delivered to a server. This may imply what configuration tool is going to perform the configuration.

OS::Heat::StructuredDeployment.description:
A resource which has same logic with OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment.

A deployment resource like OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment, but which
performs input value substitution on the config defined by a
OS::Heat::StructuredConfig resource.

Some configuration tools have no concept of inputs, so the input value
substitution needs to occur in the deployment resource. An example of this
is the JSON metadata consumed by the cfn-init tool.

Where the config contains {get_input: input_name} this will be substituted
with the value of input_name in this resource's input_values. If get_input
needs to be passed through to the substituted configuration then a
different input_key property value can be specified.

deploy_stdout.description: Captured stdout from the configuration execution.

deploy_stderr.description: Captured stderr from the configuration execution.

deploy_status_code.description: Returned status code from the configuration execution.

input_key.description: Name of key to use for substituting inputs during deployment.

signal_transport.description: How the server should signal to heat with the deployment output values. CFN_SIGNAL will allow an HTTP POST to a CFN keypair signed URL. TEMP_URL_SIGNAL will create a Swift TempURL to be signaled via HTTP PUT. HEAT_SIGNAL will allow calls to the Heat API resource-signal using the provided keystone credentials. ZAQAR_SIGNAL will create a dedicated zaqar queue to be signaled using the provided keystone credentials. NO_SIGNAL will result in the resource going to the COMPLETE state without waiting for any signal.

name.description: Name of the derived config associated with this deployment. This is used to apply a sort order to the list of configurations currently deployed to a server.

actions.description: Which lifecycle actions of the deployment resource will result in this deployment being triggered.

input_values_validate.description: Perform a check on the input values passed to verify that each required input has a corresponding value. When the property is set to STRICT and no value is passed, an exception is raised.

input_values.description: Input values to apply to the software configuration on this server.

server.description: ID of resource to apply configuration to. Normally this should be a Nova server ID.

config.description: ID of software configuration resource to execute when applying to the server.

OS::Heat::StructuredDeploymentGroup.description:
This resource associates a group of servers with some configuration.

This resource works similar as OS::Heat::SoftwareDeploymentGroup, but for
structured resources.

deploy_stderrs.description: A map of Nova names and captured stderrs from the configuration execution to each server.

deploy_stdouts.description: A map of Nova names and captured stdouts from the configuration execution to each server.

deploy_status_codes.description: A map of Nova names and returned status code from the configuration execution.

input_key.description: Name of key to use for substituting inputs during deployment.

signal_transport.description: How the server should signal to heat with the deployment output values. CFN_SIGNAL will allow an HTTP POST to a CFN keypair signed URL. TEMP_URL_SIGNAL will create a Swift TempURL to be signaled via HTTP PUT. HEAT_SIGNAL will allow calls to the Heat API resource-signal using the provided keystone credentials. ZAQAR_SIGNAL will create a dedicated zaqar queue to be signaled using the provided keystone credentials. NO_SIGNAL will result in the resource going to the COMPLETE state without waiting for any signal.

name.description: Name of the derived config associated with this deployment. This is used to apply a sort order to the list of configurations currently deployed to a server.

actions.description: Which lifecycle actions of the deployment resource will result in this deployment being triggered.

input_values_validate.description: Perform a check on the input values passed to verify that each required input has a corresponding value. When the property is set to STRICT and no value is passed, an exception is raised.

input_values.description: Input values to apply to the software configuration on this server.

servers.description: A map of names and server IDs to apply configuration to. The name is arbitrary and is used as the Heat resource name for the corresponding deployment.

config.description: ID of software configuration resource to execute when applying to the server.

OS::Heat::TestResource.description:
A resource which stores the string value that was provided.

This resource is to be used only for testing.
It has control knobs such as 'update_replace', 'fail', 'wait_secs'.

output.description: The string that was stored. This value is also available by referencing the resource.

wait_secs.description: Seconds to wait after an action (-1 is infinite).

update_replace_value.description: Some value that can be stored but can not be updated.

value.description: The input string to be stored.

create.description: Seconds to wait after a create. Defaults to the global wait_secs.

update.description: Seconds to wait after an update. Defaults to the global wait_secs.

delete.description: Seconds to wait after a delete. Defaults to the global wait_secs.

attr_wait_secs.description: Number value for timeout during resolving output value.

constraint_prop_secs.description: Number value for delay during resolve constraint.

fail.description: Value which can be set to fail the resource operation to test failure scenarios.

update_replace.description: Value which can be set to trigger update replace for the particular resource.

OS::Heat::UpdateWaitConditionHandle.description:
WaitConditionHandle that clears signals and changes handle on update.

This works identically to a regular WaitConditionHandle, except that
on update it clears all signals received and changes the handle. Using
this handle means that you must setup the signal senders to send their
signals again any time the update handle changes. This allows us to roll
out new configurations and be confident that they are rolled out once
UPDATE COMPLETE is reached.

OS::Heat::Value.description:
A resource which exposes its value property as an attribute.

This is useful for exposing a value that is a simple manipulation
of other template parameters and/or other resources.

value.description: The value generated by this resource's properties "value" expression, with type determined from the properties "type".
The expression to generate the "value" attribute.

OS::Heat::WaitCondition.description:
Resource for handling signals received by WaitConditionHandle.

Resource takes WaitConditionHandle and starts to create. Resource is in
CREATE_IN_PROGRESS status until WaitConditionHandle doesn't receive
sufficient number of successful signals (this number can be specified with
count property) and successfully creates after that, or fails due to
timeout.

data.description: JSON string containing data associated with wait condition signals sent to the handle.

count.description: The number of success signals that must be received before the stack creation process continues.

handle.description: A reference to the wait condition handle used to signal this wait condition.

timeout.description: The number of seconds to wait for the correct number of signals to arrive.

OS::Heat::WaitConditionHandle.description:
Resource for managing instance signals.

The main points of this resource are:
- have no dependencies (so the instance can reference it).
- create credentials to allow for signalling from the instance.
- handle signals from the instance, validate and store result.

curl_cli.description: Convenience attribute, provides curl CLI command prefix, which can be used for signalling handle completion or failure when signal_transport is set to TOKEN_SIGNAL. You can signal success by adding --data-binary '{"status": "SUCCESS"}' , or signal failure by adding --data-binary '{"status": "FAILURE"}'. This attribute is set to None for all other signal transports.

token.description: Token for stack-user which can be used for signalling handle when signal_transport is set to TOKEN_SIGNAL. None for all other signal transports.

endpoint.description: Endpoint/url which can be used for signalling handle when signal_transport is set to TOKEN_SIGNAL. None for all other signal transports.

signal.description: JSON serialized map that includes the endpoint, token and/or other attributes the client must use for signalling this handle. The contents of this map depend on the type of signal selected in the signal_transport property.

signal_transport.description: How the client will signal the wait condition. CFN_SIGNAL will allow an HTTP POST to a CFN keypair signed URL. TEMP_URL_SIGNAL will create a Swift TempURL to be signalled via HTTP PUT. HEAT_SIGNAL will allow calls to the Heat API resource-signal using the provided keystone credentials. ZAQAR_SIGNAL will create a dedicated zaqar queue to be signalled using the provided keystone credentials. TOKEN_SIGNAL will allow and HTTP POST to a Heat API endpoint with the provided keystone token. NO_SIGNAL will result in the resource going to a signalled state without waiting for any signal.

OS::Neutron::AddressScope.description:
A resource for Neutron address scope.

This resource can be associated with multiple subnet pools
in a one-to-many relationship. The subnet pools under an
address scope must not overlap.

ip_version.description: Address family of the address scope, which is 4 or 6.

shared.description: Whether the address scope should be shared to other tenants. Note that the default policy setting restricts usage of this attribute to administrative users only, and restricts changing of shared address scope to unshared with update.

name.description: The name for the address scope.

tenant_id.description: The owner tenant ID of the address scope. Only administrative users can specify a tenant ID other than their own.

OS::Neutron::ExtraRoute.description:
Resource for specifying extra routes for Neutron router.

Resource allows to specify nexthop IP and destination network for router.

support_status.message: Use this resource at your own risk.

OS::Neutron::FloatingIP.description:
A resource for managing Neutron floating ips.

Floating IP addresses can change their association between routers by
action of the user. One of the most common use cases for floating IPs is
to provide public IP addresses to a private cloud, where there are a
limited number of IP addresses available. Another is for a public cloud
user to have a "static" IP address that can be reassigned when an instance
is upgraded or moved.

router_id.description: ID of the router used as gateway, set when associated with a port.

tenant_id.description: The tenant owning this floating IP.

floating_network_id.description: ID of the network in which this IP is allocated.

fixed_ip_address.description: IP address of the associated port, if specified.

floating_ip_address.description: The allocated address of this IP.

port_id.description: ID of the port associated with this IP.

floating_network.description: Network to allocate floating IP from.

dns_name.description: DNS name associated with floating ip.

dns_domain.description: DNS domain associated with floating ip.

fixed_ip_address.description: IP address to use if the port has multiple addresses.

floating_ip_address.description: IP address of the floating IP. NOTE: The default policy setting in Neutron restricts usage of this property to administrative users only.

value_specs.description: Extra parameters to include in the "floatingip" object in the creation request. Parameters are often specific to installed hardware or extensions.

port_id.description: ID of an existing port with at least one IP address to associate with this floating IP.

OS::Neutron::FloatingIPAssociation.description:
A resource for associating floating ips and ports.

This resource allows associating a floating IP to a port with at least one
IP address to associate with this floating IP.

floatingip_id.description: ID of the floating IP to associate.

fixed_ip_address.description: IP address to use if the port has multiple addresses.

port_id.description: ID of an existing port with at least one IP address to associate with this floating IP.

OS::Neutron::FlowClassifier.description:
"Heat Template Resource for networking-sfc flow-classifier.

This resource used to select the traffic that can access the service chain.
Traffic that matches any flow classifier will be directed to the first
port in the chain.

protocol.description: IP Protocol for the Flow Classifier.

logical_destination_port.description: ID or name of the neutron destination port.

logical_source_port.description: ID or name of the neutron source port.

OS::Neutron::MeteringLabel.description:
A resource for creating neutron metering label.

The idea is to meter this at the L3 routers levels. The point is to allow
operators to configure IP ranges and to assign a label to them. For example
we will be able to set two labels; one for the internal traffic, and the
other one for the external traffic. Each label will measure the traffic for
a specific set of IP range. Then, bandwidth measurement will be sent for
each label to the Oslo notification system and could be collected by
Ceilometer.

shared.description: Shared status of the metering label.
Whether the metering label should be shared across all tenants.

OS::Neutron::MeteringRule.description:
A resource to create rule for some label.

Resource for allowing specified label to measure the traffic for a specific
set of ip range.

remote_ip_prefix.description: CIDR to be associated with this metering rule.

direction.description: The direction in which metering rule is applied.

metering_label_id.description: The metering label ID to associate with this metering rule.

remote_ip_prefix.description: Indicates remote IP prefix to be associated with this metering rule.

direction.description: The direction in which metering rule is applied, either ingress or egress.

metering_label_id.description: The metering label ID to associate with this metering rule.

excluded.description: Specify whether the remote_ip_prefix will be excluded or not from traffic counters of the metering label. For example to not count the traffic of a specific IP address of a range.

OS::Neutron::Net.description:
A resource for managing Neutron net.

A network is a virtual isolated layer-2 broadcast domain which is typically
reserved to the tenant who created it, unless the network has been
explicitly configured to be shared.

qos_policy_id.description: The QoS policy ID attached to this network.

admin_state_up.description: The administrative status of the network.

mtu.description: The maximum transmission unit size(in bytes) for the network.

port_security_enabled.description: Port security enabled of the network.

dhcp_agent_ids.description: The IDs of the DHCP agent to schedule the network. Note that the default policy setting in Neutron restricts usage of this property to administrative users only.

name.description: A string specifying a symbolic name for the network, which is not required to be unique.

admin_state_up.description: A boolean value specifying the administrative status of the network.

tenant_id.description: The ID of the tenant which will own the network. Only administrative users can set the tenant identifier; this cannot be changed using authorization policies.

dns_domain.description: DNS domain associated with this network.

value_specs.description: Extra parameters to include in the request. Parameters are often specific to installed hardware or extensions.

port_security_enabled.description: Flag to enable/disable port security on the network. It provides the default value for the attribute of the ports created on this network.

shared.description: Whether this network should be shared across all tenants. Note that the default policy setting restricts usage of this attribute to administrative users only.

qos_policy.description: The name or ID of QoS policy to attach to this network.

OS::Neutron::NetworkGateway.description:
Network Gateway resource in Neutron Network Gateway.

Resource for connecting internal networks with specified devices.

default.description: A boolean value of default flag.

connections.description: Connection info for this network gateway.

segmentation_id.description: The id for L2 segment on the external side of the network gateway. Must be specified when using vlan.

segmentation_type.description: L2 segmentation strategy on the external side of the network gateway.

network.description: The internal network to connect on the network gateway.

name.description: The name of the network gateway.

devices.description: Device info for this network gateway.

interface_name.description: The interface name for the network gateway.

id.description: The device id for the network gateway.

OS::Neutron::Port.description:
A resource for managing Neutron ports.

A port represents a virtual switch port on a logical network switch.
Virtual instances attach their interfaces into ports. The logical port also
defines the MAC address and the IP address(es) to be assigned to the
interfaces plugged into them. When IP addresses are associated to a port,
this also implies the port is associated with a subnet, as the IP address
was taken from the allocation pool for a specific subnet.

subnets.description: A list of all subnet attributes for the port.

allowed_address_pairs.description: Additional MAC/IP address pairs allowed to pass through a port.

network_id.description: Unique identifier for the network owning the port.

admin_state_up.description: The administrative state of this port.

dns_assignment.description: The DNS assigned to this port.

device_owner.description: Name of the network owning the port.

qos_policy_id.description: The QoS policy ID attached to this port.

port_security_enabled.description: Port security enabled of the port.

security_groups.description: A list of security groups for the port.

replacement_policy.description: Policy on how to respond to a stack-update for this resource. REPLACE_ALWAYS will replace the port regardless of any property changes. AUTO will update the existing port for any changed update-allowed property.

name.description: A symbolic name for this port.

allowed_address_pairs.description: Additional MAC/IP address pairs allowed to pass through the port.

ip_address.description: IP address to allow through this port.

mac_address.description: MAC address to allow through this port.

admin_state_up.description: The administrative state of this port.

dns_name.description: DNS name associated with the port.

binding:vnic_type.description: The vnic type to be bound on the neutron port. To support SR-IOV PCI passthrough networking, you can request that the neutron port to be realized as normal (virtual nic), direct (pci passthrough), or macvtap (virtual interface with a tap-like software interface). Note that this only works for Neutron deployments that support the bindings extension.

network.description: Network this port belongs to. If you plan to use current port to assign Floating IP, you should specify fixed_ips with subnet. Note if this changes to a different network update, the port will be replaced.

device_owner.description: Name of the network owning the port. The value is typically network:floatingip or network:router_interface or network:dhcp.

value_specs.description: Extra parameters to include in the request.

mac_address.description: MAC address to give to this port. The default update policy of this property in neutron is that allow admin role only.

port_security_enabled.description: Flag to enable/disable port security on the port. When disable this feature(set it to False), there will be no packages filtering, like security-group and address-pairs.

qos_policy.description: The name or ID of QoS policy to attach to this port.

subnet.description: Subnet in which to allocate the IP address for this port.

ip_address.description: IP address desired in the subnet for this port.

security_groups.description: Security group IDs to associate with this port.

OS::Neutron::PortPair.description:
A resource for neutron networking-sfc port-pair.

This plug-in requires networking-sfc>=1.0.0. So to enable this
plug-in, install this library and restart the heat-engine.

A Port Pair represents a service function instance. The ingress port and
the egress port of the service function may be specified. If a service
function has one bidirectional port, the ingress port has the same value
as the egress port.

ingress.description: ID or name of the ingress neutron port.

egress.description: ID or name of the egress neutron port.

service_function_parameters.description: Dictionary of service function parameter. Currently only correlation=None is supported.

OS::Neutron::ProviderNet.description:
A resource for managing Neutron provider networks.

Provider networks specify details of physical realisation of the existing
network.

name.description: A string specifying a symbolic name for the network, which is not required to be unique.

admin_state_up.description: A boolean value specifying the administrative status of the network.

router_external.description: Whether the network contains an external router.

segmentation_id.description: A string specifying the segmentation id for the network.

physical_network.description: A string specifying physical network mapping for the network.

shared.description: Whether this network should be shared across all tenants.

port_security_enabled.description: Flag to enable/disable port security on the network. It provides the default value for the attribute of the ports created on this network.

network_type.description: A string specifying the provider network type for the network.

OS::Neutron::RBACPolicy.description:
A Resource for managing RBAC policy in Neutron.

This resource creates and manages Neutron RBAC policy,
which allows to share Neutron networks to subsets of tenants.

tenant_id.description: The owner tenant ID. Only required if the caller has an administrative role and wants to create a RBAC for another tenant.

object_type.description: Type of the object that RBAC policy affects.

target_tenant.description: ID of the tenant to which the RBAC policy will be enforced.

object_id.description: ID or name of the RBAC object.

OS::Neutron::Router.description:
A resource that implements Neutron router.

Router is a physical or virtual network device that passes network traffic
between different networks.

external_gateway_info.description: External network gateway configuration for a router.

enable_snat.description: Enables Source NAT on the router gateway. NOTE: The default policy setting in Neutron restricts usage of this property to administrative users only.

network.description: ID or name of the external network for the gateway.

external_fixed_ips.description: External fixed IP addresses for the gateway.

subnet.description: Subnet of external fixed IP address.

admin_state_up.description: The administrative state of the router.

distributed.description: Indicates whether or not to create a distributed router. NOTE: The default policy setting in Neutron restricts usage of this property to administrative users only. This property can not be used in conjunction with the L3 agent ID.

value_specs.description: Extra parameters to include in the creation request.

ha.description: Indicates whether or not to create a highly available router. NOTE: The default policy setting in Neutron restricts usage of this property to administrative users only. And now neutron do not support distributed and ha at the same time.

l3_agent_ids.description: ID list of the L3 agent. User can specify multi-agents for highly available router. NOTE: The default policy setting in Neutron restricts usage of this property to administrative users only.

OS::Neutron::RouterInterface.description:
A resource for managing Neutron router interfaces.

Router interfaces associate routers with existing subnets or ports.

subnet.description: The subnet, either subnet or port should be specified.

port.description: The port, either subnet or port should be specified.

OS::Neutron::SecurityGroup.description:
A resource for managing Neutron security groups.

Security groups are sets of IP filter rules that are applied to an
instance's networking. They are project specific, and project members can
edit the default rules for their group and add new rules sets. All projects
have a "default" security group, which is applied to instances that have no
other security group defined.

remote_group_id.description: The remote group ID to be associated with this security group rule. If no value is specified then this rule will use this security group for the remote_group_id. The remote mode parameter must be set to "remote_group_id".

direction.description: The direction in which the security group rule is applied. For a compute instance, an ingress security group rule matches traffic that is incoming (ingress) for that instance. An egress rule is applied to traffic leaving the instance.

remote_ip_prefix.description: The remote IP prefix (CIDR) to be associated with this security group rule.

protocol.description: The protocol that is matched by the security group rule. Valid values include tcp, udp, and icmp.

port_range_max.description: The maximum port number in the range that is matched by the security group rule. The port_range_min attribute constrains the port_range_max attribute. If the protocol is ICMP, this value must be an ICMP type.

port_range_min.description: The minimum port number in the range that is matched by the security group rule. If the protocol is TCP or UDP, this value must be less than or equal to the value of the port_range_max attribute. If the protocol is ICMP, this value must be an ICMP type.

remote_mode.description: Whether to specify a remote group or a remote IP prefix.

name.description: A string specifying a symbolic name for the security group, which is not required to be unique.

OS::Neutron::SecurityGroupRule.description:
A resource for managing Neutron security group rules.

Rules to use in security group resource.

direction.description: The direction in which the security group rule is applied. For a compute instance, an ingress security group rule matches traffic that is incoming (ingress) for that instance. An egress rule is applied to traffic leaving the instance.

protocol.description: The protocol that is matched by the security group rule. Allowed values are ah, dccp, egp, esp, gre, icmp, icmpv6, igmp, ipv6-encap, ipv6-frag, ipv6-icmp, ipv6-nonxt, ipv6-opts, ipv6-route, ospf, pgm, rsvp, sctp, tcp, udp, udplite, vrrp and integer representations [0-255].

description.description: Description of the security group rule.

remote_ip_prefix.description: The remote IP prefix (CIDR) to be associated with this security group rule.

port_range_max.description: The maximum port number in the range that is matched by the security group rule. The port_range_min attribute constrains the port_range_max attribute. If the protocol is ICMP, this value must be an ICMP code.

port_range_min.description: The minimum port number in the range that is matched by the security group rule. If the protocol is TCP or UDP, this value must be less than or equal to the value of the port_range_max attribute. If the protocol is ICMP, this value must be an ICMP type.

security_group.description: Security group name or ID to add rule.

remote_group.description: The remote group name or ID to be associated with this security group rule.

OS::Neutron::Subnet.description:
A resource for managing Neutron subnets.

A subnet represents an IP address block that can be used for assigning IP
addresses to virtual instances. Each subnet must have a CIDR and must be
associated with a network. IPs can be either selected from the whole subnet
CIDR, or from "allocation pools" that can be specified by the user.

enable_dhcp.description: 'true' if DHCP is enabled for this subnet; 'false' otherwise.

allocation_pools.description: Ip allocation pools and their ranges.

cidr.description: CIDR block notation for this subnet.

network.description: The ID of the attached network.

enable_dhcp.description: Set to true if DHCP is enabled and false if DHCP is disabled.

tenant_id.description: The ID of the tenant who owns the network. Only administrative users can specify a tenant ID other than their own.

subnetpool.description: The name or ID of the subnet pool.

dns_nameservers.description: A specified set of DNS name servers to be used.

gateway_ip.description: The gateway IP address. Set to any of [ null | ~ | "" ] to create/update a subnet without a gateway. If omitted when creation, neutron will assign the first free IP address within the subnet to the gateway automatically. If remove this from template when update, the old gateway IP address will be detached.

allocation_pools.description: The start and end addresses for the allocation pools.

start.description: Start address for the allocation pool.

end.description: End address for the allocation pool.

host_routes.description: A list of host route dictionaries for the subnet.

nexthop.description: The next hop for the destination.

value_specs.description: Extra parameters to include in the request.

prefixlen.description: Prefix length for subnet allocation from subnet pool.

ip_version.description: The IP version, which is 4 or 6.

OS::Neutron::SubnetPool.description:
A resource that implements neutron subnet pool.

This resource can be used to create a subnet pool with a large block
of addresses and create subnets from it.

is_default.description: Whether this is default IPv4/IPv6 subnet pool. There can only be one default subnet pool for each IP family. Note that the default policy setting restricts administrative users to set this to True.

default_quota.description: A per-tenant quota on the prefix space that can be allocated from the subnet pool for tenant subnets.

tenant_id.description: The ID of the tenant who owns the subnet pool. Only administrative users can specify a tenant ID other than their own.

prefixes.description: List of subnet prefixes to assign.

min_prefixlen.description: Smallest prefix size that can be allocated from the subnet pool.

shared.description: Whether the subnet pool will be shared across all tenants. Note that the default policy setting restricts usage of this attribute to administrative users only.

default_prefixlen.description: The size of the prefix to allocate when the cidr or prefixlen attributes are not specified while creating a subnet.

address_scope.description: An address scope ID to assign to the subnet pool.

max_prefixlen.description: Maximum prefix size that can be allocated from the subnet pool.

OS::Nova::FloatingIP.description:
A resource for managing Nova floating IPs.

Floating IP addresses can change their association between instances by
action of the user. One of the most common use cases for floating IPs is
to provide public IP addresses to a private cloud, where there are a
limited number of IP addresses available. Another is for a public cloud
user to have a "static" IP address that can be reassigned when an instance
is upgraded or moved.

pool.description: Pool from which floating IP is allocated.
Allocate a floating IP from a given floating IP pool.

OS::Nova::FloatingIPAssociation.description:
A resource associates Nova floating IP with Nova server resource.

Resource for associating existing Nova floating IP and Nova server.

server_id.description: Server to assign floating IP to.

floating_ip.description: ID of the floating IP to assign to the server.

OS::Nova::KeyPair.description:
A resource for creating Nova key pairs.

A keypair is a ssh key that can be injected into a server on launch.

**Note** that if a new key is generated setting `save_private_key` to
`True` results in the system saving the private key which can then be
retrieved via the `private_key` attribute of this resource.

Setting the `public_key` property means that the `private_key` attribute
of this resource will always return an empty string regardless of the
`save_private_key` setting since there will be no private key data to
save.

private_key.description: The private key if it has been saved.

public_key.description: The optional public key. This allows users to supply the public key from a pre-existing key pair. If not supplied, a new key pair will be generated.

type.description: Keypair type. Supported since Nova api version 2.2.

name.description: The name of the key pair.

save_private_key.description: True if the system should remember a generated private key; False otherwise.

OS::Nova::Server.description:
A resource for managing Nova instances.

A Server resource manages the running virtual machine instance within an
OpenStack cloud.

console_urls.description: URLs of server's consoles. To get a specific console type, the requested type can be specified as parameter to the get_attr function, e.g. get_attr: [ <server>, console_urls, novnc ]. Currently supported types are novnc, xvpvnc, spice-html5, rdp-html5, serial.

tags.description: Tags from the server. Supported since client version 2.26.

accessIPv4.description: The manually assigned alternative public IPv4 address of the server.

accessIPv6.description: The manually assigned alternative public IPv6 address of the server.

networks.description: A dict of assigned network addresses of the form: {"public": [ip1, ip2...], "private": [ip3, ip4], "public_uuid": [ip1, ip2...], "private_uuid": [ip3, ip4]}. Each network will have two keys in dict, they are network name and network id.

addresses.description: A dict of all network addresses with corresponding port_id. Each network will have two keys in dict, they are network name and network id. The port ID may be obtained through the following expression: "{get_attr: [<server>, addresses, <network name_or_id>, 0, port]}".

admin_pass.description: The administrator password for the server.

user_data_update_policy.description: Policy on how to apply a user_data update; either by ignoring it or by replacing the entire server.

availability_zone.description: Name of the availability zone for server placement.

image.description: The ID or name of the image to boot with.

user_data.description: User data script to be executed by cloud-init.

diskConfig.description: Control how the disk is partitioned when the server is created.

flavor_update_policy.description: Policy on how to apply a flavor update; either by requesting a server resize or by replacing the entire server.

flavor.description: The ID or name of the flavor to boot onto.

reservation_id.description: A UUID for the set of servers being requested.

networks.description: An ordered list of nics to be added to this server, with information about connected networks, fixed ips, port etc.

subnet.description: Subnet in which to allocate the IP address for port. Used for creating port, based on derived properties. If subnet is specified, network property becomes optional.

uuid.description: ID of network to create a port on.

fixed_ip.description: Fixed IP address to specify for the port created on the requested network.

floating_ip.description: ID of the floating IP to associate.

port_extra_properties.description: Dict, which has expand properties for port. Used only if port property is not specified for creating port.

allowed_address_pairs.description: Additional MAC/IP address pairs allowed to pass through the port.

ip_address.description: IP address to allow through this port.

mac_address.description: MAC address to allow through this port.

admin_state_up.description: The administrative state of this port.

binding:vnic_type.description: The vnic type to be bound on the neutron port. To support SR-IOV PCI passthrough networking, you can request that the neutron port to be realized as normal (virtual nic), direct (pci passthrough), or macvtap (virtual interface with a tap-like software interface). Note that this only works for Neutron deployments that support the bindings extension.

value_specs.description: Extra parameters to include in the request.

mac_address.description: MAC address to give to this port. The default update policy of this property in neutron is that allow admin role only.

port_security_enabled.description: Flag to enable/disable port security on the port. When disable this feature(set it to False), there will be no packages filtering, like security-group and address-pairs.

qos_policy.description: The name or ID of QoS policy to attach to this port.

port.description: ID of an existing port to associate with this server.

network.description: Name or ID of network to create a port on.

security_groups.description: List of security group names or IDs. Cannot be used if neutron ports are associated with this server; assign security groups to the ports instead.

scheduler_hints.description: Arbitrary key-value pairs specified by the client to help boot a server.

tags.description: Server tags. Supported since client version 2.26.

config_drive.description: If True, enable config drive on the server.

personality.description: A map of files to create/overwrite on the server upon boot. Keys are file names and values are the file contents.

user_data_format.description: How the user_data should be formatted for the server. For HEAT_CFNTOOLS, the user_data is bundled as part of the heat-cfntools cloud-init boot configuration data. For RAW the user_data is passed to Nova unmodified. For SOFTWARE_CONFIG user_data is bundled as part of the software config data, and metadata is derived from any associated SoftwareDeployment resources.

block_device_mapping.description: Block device mappings for this server.

device_name.description: A device name where the volume will be attached in the system at /dev/device_name. This value is typically vda.

volume_size.description: The size of the volume, in GB. It is safe to leave this blank and have the Compute service infer the size.

volume_id.description: The ID of the volume to boot from. Only one of volume_id or snapshot_id should be provided.

delete_on_termination.description: Indicate whether the volume should be deleted when the server is terminated.

snapshot_id.description: The ID of the snapshot to create a volume from.

key_name.description: Name of keypair to inject into the server.

software_config_transport.description: How the server should receive the metadata required for software configuration. POLL_SERVER_CFN will allow calls to the cfn API action DescribeStackResource authenticated with the provided keypair. POLL_SERVER_HEAT will allow calls to the Heat API resource-show using the provided keystone credentials. POLL_TEMP_URL will create and populate a Swift TempURL with metadata for polling. ZAQAR_MESSAGE will create a dedicated zaqar queue and post the metadata for polling.

block_device_mapping_v2.description: Block device mappings v2 for this server.

ephemeral_format.description: The format of the local ephemeral block device. If no format is specified, uses default value, defined in nova configuration file.

boot_index.description: Integer used for ordering the boot disks.

ephemeral_size.description: The size of the local ephemeral block device, in GB.

volume_size.description: Size of the block device in GB. If it is omitted, hypervisor driver calculates size.

image.description: The ID or name of the image to create a volume from.

volume_id.description: The volume_id can be boot or non-boot device to the server.

device_type.description: Device type: at the moment we can make distinction only between disk and cdrom.

device_name.description: A device name where the volume will be attached in the system at /dev/device_name. This value is typically vda.

disk_bus.description: Bus of the device: hypervisor driver chooses a suitable default if omitted.

image_id.description: The ID of the image to create a volume from.

swap_size.description: The size of the swap, in MB.

snapshot_id.description: The ID of the snapshot to create a volume from.

delete_on_termination.description: Indicate whether the volume should be deleted when the server is terminated.

image_update_policy.description: Policy on how to apply an image-id update; either by requesting a server rebuild or by replacing the entire server.

metadata.description: Arbitrary key/value metadata to store for this server. Both keys and values must be 255 characters or less. Non-string values will be serialized to JSON (and the serialized string must be 255 characters or less).

OS::Nova::ServerGroup.description:
A resource for managing a Nova server group.

Server groups allow you to make sure instances (VM/VPS) are on the same
hypervisor host or on a different one.

policies.description: A list of string policies to apply. Defaults to anti-affinity.
